profileText: A Representative from Pennsylvania; born in Philadelphia, Pa., June 14, 1786; pursued a classical course and was graduated from Princeton College in 1804; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Philadelphia, Pa.; elected as an Anti-Jacksonian candidate to the Twenty-fourth Congress (March 4, 1835-March 3, 1837); declined to be a candidate for renomination in 1836; resumed the practice of law; elected as a Whig to the Twenty-seventh Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of John Sergeant; reelected as a Whig to the Twenty-eighth, Twenty-ninth, and Thirtieth Congresses and served from October 12, 1841, to March 3, 1849; chairman, Committee on the Judiciary (Thirtieth Congress); declined to accept the nomination as a candidate for reelection in 1848 to the Thirty-first Congress; appointed Minister to Great Britain by President Fillmore and served from August 21, 1852, to August 23, 1853; died in Philadelphia, Pa., February 20, 1868; interment in St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Churchyard.

note.content: One of two elected to represent the second district.
Elected to fill vacancy caused by resignation of John Sergeant, and took his seat December 9, 1841.
One of two elected to represent the second district.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Brown, David Paul. Eulogium on the life and character of the late Hon. Joseph Reed Ingersoll. Philadelphia: Collins, printer, 1869.
Ingersoll, Joseph Reed. An address delivered at the opening of the Wills Hospital for Indigent Blind and Lame. Philadelphia: Printed by J. Kay, Jun. and Co., [1834].
------. An address, delivered before the Demosthenian and Phi Kappa Societies of the University of Georgia. Athens, Ga.: Christy & Lampkin, printers, 1847.
------. Address delivered before the Franklin Institute of the State of Pennsylvania. Philadelphia: King & Baird, printers, 1848.
------. Address delivered before the National Convention of Young Men's Societies for Moral and Intellectual Improvement, October 29, 1834. Philadelphia: Printed by J. Kay, [1834].
------. An address delivered in the church at Princeton. [Princeton]: Princeton Press, 1828.
------. Annual discourse before the Philomathean Society of the University of Pennsylvania. Philadelphia: Carey, Lea and Carey, 1827.
------. Memoir of the late Samuel Breck, Vice-president of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania. Philadelphia: King & Baird, printers, 1863.

------. Memoir of the late Samuel Breck, Vice-president of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania. Read before the Society, by Joseph R. Ingersoll, January 12th, 1863. Philadelphia: King & Baird, printers, 1863.
------. National institute [Washington, D. C.] New York: N.p., 1845].
------. An oration delivered before the Washington Benevolent Society, at their anniversary meeting, July 5, 1813. Philadelphia: Printed at the office of theUnited States' Gazette, 1813.
------. Speech of Joseph R. Ingersoll, on the Oregon bill: Delivered in the House of Representatives of the United States, April 16, 1846. Washington: Printed by Gales and Seaton, 1846.
------. Speech of Joseph R. Ingersoll, on the subtreasury bill: Delivered in the House of Representatives of the United States, March 31, 1846. Washington: Printed by Gales and Seaton, 1846.

------. Speech of Mr. Ingersoll, of Pennsylvania, on the bill making appropriations for certain fortifications, before a Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, May 24, 1836. [Washington? D.C.: N.p., 1836].

researchRecord.name: In the papers of Charles Jared Ingersoll, 1803-1862, 675 items.
